review_title: Extremely strong staff pool, floundering leadership and low morale
pros: The staff are best in class - and the new hires are even better. Staff love the org, love their colleagues, and love the work. The vast majority are highly motivated to be on a path of constant improvement and collective decision-making and learning - the days of condescending know-it-alls are largely in the rear-view mirror (though a few remnants still linger). I've had excellent managers, made life-long friends, and have experienced great personal and professional growth because of my time with NRDC. The pay and benefits are well above market compared to similar non-profit orgs.
cons: Leadership - many of whom are relatively new to the organization - don't seem to have control over the cultural and financial issues the org is facing right now. There hasn't been time allowed to build trust with new leadership, and the few touchpoints have fostered an air of skepticism. The culture, once strong, has faltered post covid. I really feel bad for new staff who didn't get to experience the exuberance of the office culture of yesteryear. I don't think mandatory time back in the office will do any good (would likely just build resentment), but something needs to change. Morale is at an all time low, at least in the last six years I've been here.

pros: I am a better person because of my time at NRDC. Great talent, nurturing team, impressive role models. The work NRDC does is critical and I will forever be grateful for the experience. The place is going through a challenging time, with new executives, and cycles of strategic planning. The culture has improved with new leadership specially the Chief HR Officer who is a breath of fresh air and equally compassionate and transparent (she is caring with strong candor - no b.s.! ). Unfortunately she has her work cut out for her with an HR team that doesn't seem to really care about people, too bureaucratic, lacks even the most basic DEI knowledge, and has had years and years of distrust built. The DEI team is being rebuilt with new expertise that I hope can make a real difference from many misses in the past.
cons: I had strong managers in my team that were empathetic and caring. I was lucky. But there is a lack of strong and skilled managers throughout NRDC. BIPOC community on all levels continue to struggle with being seen, heard, valued. Excacerbated by an awful HR team (other than the Chief HR Officer) who couldn't care less about people, lack of DEI support knowledge and practices across that continue to be harmful.

pros: I love fighting the good fight with true NRDCers. It truly feels like paying it forward to the next generation each day. Fair compensation, good benefits, and the current hybrid work arrangement is the best. The organization is invested in the employees' well-being, professional development, and building cultural identity.
cons: I have never known any other employer where leadership lets employees control the organization's directives. It is all about what's in it for me and not the success of our mission. This is not the way to be good stewards of our donor's money. The organization will lose many good-intended and accomplished professionals if they do not set up parameters to stop well-known individuals with hidden personal agendas from sabotaging our true mission. These individuals' social media does not match their true character. Based on previous comments, there is no surprise that the employee blames the HR Team since they are left to deal with all the issues that leadership decides to ignore by playing the political card. Organizational processes are not bad but could improve and provide more clarity. Too many meetings.

review_title: Great people, great team, great mission--typical non-profit pluses and minuses
pros: I get to work with people who are caring, humble, feisty, smart, committed, and mutually supportive on issues that matter and with a lot of autonomy. I've worked in private, government, and other non-profit settings. This is hands-down the best.
cons: The organization is big enough that some internal processes be bureaucratic and slow. My fellow staff are mostly advocates, and they often turn those skills internally in ways that are sometimes helpful, sometimes not. There has been repeated, high-level leadership change in recent years (although it's a testament to the staff that they've stayed strong throughout, and leadership changes now seem behind us). Like a lot of organizations, this one is still learning and growing on its DEI journey; there's a lot of work to do, although its commitment to doing so feels genuine.

pros: I love working here. My colleagues are brilliant and I'm constantly learning from them. They're down-to-earth and kind to one another, too, which you don't always find in mission-driven organizations; there's a real ethos of mutual support. People really make the effort to do right by one another. The work is meaningful, challenging, and energizing. Work-life balance is very good (especially compared to most legal jobs).
cons: We've been through several leadership changes over the past several years, and a new operating model is in the works; those changes have been hard on staff. But our new president, Manish Bapna, is excellent. So is our new head of Human Resources and the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. We still have a considerable way to go on internal DEI, as do all US environmental organizations, but we're heading in the right direction, with HR and ODEI staffing up and really committing resources to do the work.

pros: None, this place has fallen greatly
cons: Employees aren't valued. If you aren't one of the favorites, good luck. A particular Officer in the company has completely changed the culture for the worse. Most of the favorites (ones constantly promoted) aren't mission driven. DEI incentives are laughable at best. Good luck everyone

pros: Noble mission, (above) market rate salaries, excellent benefits, a history of notable contributions to the environmental cause
cons: At NRDC, the tail now wags the dog. Weak leadership has let inside special interest groups take over, manipulating the leadership and the entire organization with fear based on accusations of inequity, which are at best greatly overblown. As an organization with a mission to defend the environment, NRDC’s work is inherently to help improve equity in our society, and especially for communities who are disproportionately negatively impacted by environmental issues. Unfortunately, too many within NRDC are driven by their own self-interest and greed and have seized on the recent external narrative in order to extract advantage for themselves. The bitterly ironic result is that the institution gives outsized attention, time and (donated) money to greatly misguided Diversity, Equity and Inclusion initiatives that distract from work that would otherwise be helping create greater equity in society. The current Chief People and DEI Officer has taken this to a new level of absurdity bringing in a long list of expensive ‘DEI consultants and experts’ including a new DEI Office Director with a public record of discrimination, misusing funds to give bonuses to anyone who starts a new 'affinity' group, sending a barrage of platitude-laced propaganda e-mails and putting on a steady show of meetings that seem to be designed to shame weak spined leaders into continuing this distraction staffers into jumping on the bandwagon. All this is pushing this once-proud institution further into decline and further from its mission.

review_title: Experience was all over the place
pros:
- Some of the best co-workers I've ever had. 
- Some of the most intelligent people I've ever met. 
- Incredibly passionate advocates doing incredible work (usually witnessing the advocates, scientists, and attorneys more junior). 
- If you are clear on your goals of being a Program Assistant or Entry-Level, you can take advantage of the opportunity to be at NRDC and have doors and experiences opened to you. Otherwise, don't expect much upward mobility or trust from others to do more substantive work. 
- Great healthcare benefits, over-time pay was also good. 
- Traveling was fun. - It was nice to turn off my laptop at 5pm and not think about work.
cons:
- Some of the worst co-workers I've ever met especially, in my experience, working for the Arts Culture Partnership Program was the most demoralizing experience I've ever had as a professional. 
- Leadership is not in tune with the experience of anyone below a Director, also NRDC doesn't invest in their own talent. 
- Decision-making is slow. I understand and appreciate thoughtful strategy, but it is jarring how much brain space and sometimes emotional effort is put into something without measurable impact. 
- Witnessed weird, inappropriate, and offensive office dynamics with certain colleagues who had direct supervisor/direct report work relationships. I've seen favoritism, gossiping in the office, and also directors making their direct report cry or arguing publicly in work meetings, managing directors yelling at PAs and receptionists over not getting their BlueJeans meeting to work? 
- Old archaic administrative processes that could be more efficient or even automized. 
- Program Assistant morale was low while I was there, also there was always a lot of mentioning "we can't do our work without the PAs" which is true, but no real compensation. 
- As a young, queer, POC, NRDC can do so much better on the D&I efforts. I never truly felt comfortable in my own skin there. - Paternalism and perfectionism should be NRDC's motto.
- Always felt like I needed permission from someone.

pros: Passionate staff working for a good cause
cons: A lot of leadership turnover and constant re-organizing

review_title: Inequitable conditions and lack of leadership
pros: The org has a great mission and the benefits package is terrific. The hybrid work schedule, although ambiguous at the the current moment, is desirable. Work/life balance is just right. You'll find some really great individuals who genuinely care about the org's mission.
cons: Compensation is blatantly inequitable, and HR and leadership have not shown much concern, nor have they given reasoning for why this issue can't be resolved. Departments are extremely siloed, which has led to a breakdown in communication across the org and has mounted frustration for those who have to deal with it. A large number of staff won't follow standard guidelines and procedures in order to work as a collective team; guidelines aren't enforced by leadership, nor does NRDC have enterprise systems and documentation that work to standardize work across the org. And don't get me started on growth opportunities... It's a mess.

This is a large organization, so organizational decision making can be slow at times. The interests of many programs need to be balanced and thus inter-program processes can especially take time.

As with any organization, a lot of job satisfaction is dependent on relationship with managers and closest co-workers.

pros:
Great colleagues with shared vision and values. NRDC is a powerhouse with high standards. If you want to make an impact in the environmental field, it is a great place to work. It is tough confronting today's environmental challenges, but it also can be very satisfying.

Excellent benefits that are hard to match (e.g., 10% employer 401k contribution, generous family leave, great medical coverage).
cons: The work can be taxing. Lots of leadership changes also have caused internal anxiety. Fortunately, that seems to be turning around. I see a renewed spirit and excitement about the future of NRDC and our work.

review_title: save your peace and don’t work here
pros: benefits, competitive pay IF you are in the right position/right time, ability to hire talent
cons: this organization and its communications department cannot and does not want to retain people who are talented, smart, and have a genuine interest in justice. NRDC’s mission may say it wants to protect people, but in fact it does the opposite by reinforcing a toxic work culture that upholds white supremacy, ageism, and archaic methods to implement “theory of change.” in fact, extraction is their main goal, taking so much time, money, resources, ideas, and power away from staff who do not just shut up and work. sure, there are exceptions. but not enough. as a clever wolf in sheep’s clothing, the people in power are exceptional at tokenism, picking and choosing which BIPOC person to uplift, and which outspoken allies to push out— the institution also pits BIPOC and junior staff against each other by 1) offering zero upward mobility, 2) playing favorites for white folks who don’t “rock the boat,” 3) having arbitrary measures for success that are inconsistent, and 4) never holding problematic colleagues accountable. the communications department in particular cannot retain employees and acts as if everything is normal, and i have witnessed the implicit and explicit bias employees have toward interviewees of color versus mediocre white interviewees. if you fit in with the status quo (DC, political background, ivy league, attorney, centrist/a democrat, a white person, etc), you’ll have an enormously successful career at nrdc. if you’re anyone else, they will politely use you, lie to you, gaslight you, and then throw you away. save your peace, and work somewhere else. this institution wants to work on everything all at once, and does it horribly with their endless supply of money and power.

review_title: NRDC is a great place to work
pros: I have worked for several ENGO's over the years, and NRDC stands apart for several reasons. The staff are exceptionally bright and committed (many senior staff have been with the organization for 30+ years). NRDC pays relatively well, invests in its employees, encourages innovation, and is wiling to doggedly pursue even the toughest issues.
cons: Though the organization has been around since the 1970's, it very recently has seen massive growth. While NRDC has always managed money very well (the rounds of lay-offs that other NGOs sustained during the Great Recession were avoided at NRDC), its burgeoning size puts the organization at risk of increasing bureaucracy and loss of intimacy and camaraderie organization-wide. Its also generally true that mid-level staff tend to leave as the top positions rarely open (although NRDC does have a transparent and very fair promotional system that does award salary increases as experience is built).

review_title: Not much growth for Program Assistant, but great company to work for.
job_title: Program Assistant in New York, NY
pros: NRDC does great work. Hires some of the most intelligent and experienced people in the field. Great work culture.
cons: There is not a lot of room for growth especially for the assistant role, which is why there's a high turnover rate. Lots of individuals in the PA position have a high educational background but no chance to move up; either some programs don't have much opportunity for moving up or they would rather hire externally then promote from within. I guess that makes sense since the assistant role really doesn't have much opportunity for growth. No growth opportunities, no position promotion. Also, there is a bit of nepotism like any other company.

job_title: Program Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Good benefits
Good institutional knowledge in the field
Scientists and lawyers are really nice 
People are smart (and often overqualified) 
Some are great and have good ideas but are overshadowed by others
cons:
Disrespect for many people working in development from other departments and GREAT disrespect for program assistants in this position.   PAs are not treated well almost universally in this organization. Their work is often looked down upon.  I left on my own accord but in the exit interview I mentioned this and they said that they would "try" to do a training on it.  
It's almost impossible to move out of a lower tier position unless you leave for a few years and get a better job. 
They are often elitist and have fair amounts of cronyism. They talk a big talk about diversity integration but they have nothing to show for it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I enjoyed my years working at NRDC.  I was able to progress in my career during that time, and the colleagues in my department were a pleasure to work with.  Everyone at NRDC is passionate and extremely knowledgeable -- I believe that is what really makes the company so valuable.
cons: NRDC as an organization has changed since I first started to how it was when I left.  It's a lot more bureaucratic and corporate than it used to be -- but perhaps that's what's necessary for a growing organization.

review_title: Competitive compensation for a NP, but internally disorganized
pros:
+ Competitive pay & benefits compared to other nonprofits
+ Lots of genuinely smart, talented people who care deeply about the mission
+ Org is making a sincere (if not yet effective) effort to focus on diversity, equity, and inclusion.
cons:
- The org has grown too much and too quickly for the IT, HR, and facilities teams to scale. As a result, offices are very overcrowded, and the HR and IT teams are really unequipped to do their jobs. 
- The raise/promotion/performance review process is very opaque. Lots of disparate and conflicting info is made available, but managers are still left w/o answers for their employees.  (Another case of HR not being equipped to handle an org of this size.)
- Internal approvals and hierarchy bog down work. Things move very slowly, and goals are constantly shifting: projects often backtrack due to changing stakeholders/requirements, and teams aren't clear on organizational / department goals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The smartest, most passionate colleagues I've ever had. Those that work in programs and litigation are some of the most talented lawyers, scientists, and policy experts in the world.
cons: After the Trump election, NRDC sought to position itself like ACLU and Planned Parenthood; on the frontlines of our nation's defense. The problem is that up until that point, NRDC had been operating like a medium-sized, middle of the road environmental non-profit (which they are). They were completely unprepared for the rapid growth, and expanded quickly without 1) enough staff 2) enough structure to succeed. Now, we're looking backwards trying to figure out how to solve all the problems that it may be too late to fix.

review_title: The most effective conservation organization in the world.
pros: The best reason is that you're working with the best and brightest in their fields in a very influential mission-based organization. If you want to make a difference and be right in the thick of where all the action is in environmental advocacy, then this is the place to be. NRDC also offers generous benefits and top pay for an environmental nonprofit organization. NRDC takes its values very seriously. It achieves results and is respected by both its allies and opponents. The organization has a casual dress code. It offers opportunities for work that takes you out in the field to some of the places that you're working hard to protect.
cons: The biggest downsides are uneven management, non-profit salary and difficulty in achieving work/life balance.

review_title: Great mission, good people, messy management
pros: NRDC is a mission-driven place and allows individuals to do some real good in the world. I am always proud to say I work for NRDC. There is flexibility to do different things as long as you can find a champion and (if needed) funding to do the work. Lots of lifelong employees and many women in management because the work-life balance is top notch. Offices are great and the technology is improving.
cons: NRDC seems to be going through some growing pains and the management is not great. Maybe once the new president is settled and when they get the new strategic plan things will be more streamlined.

job_title: Program Assistant in New York, NY

cons: There is limited room for upward mobility for entry to mid level employees. As many of the staff had been there for decades, there was pushback against major institutional changes.

review_title: Committed and Kind, but in Need of Equity Update
pros:
I have never had a better job. I looked forward to seeing my coworkers and felt completely respected and strongly supported by my supervisors. I felt committed to the mission and believed in the organization's ability to do the work well. The attorneys I supported invited me into substantive issues that I found interesting and encouraged me to pursue career growth. I will forever be grateful for the opportunity this job provided for me to begin a career in this field.

Healthcare benefit is very good and most programs respect need to work from home or support moving to less than full-time to accommodate families.
cons:
Salary offers take advantage of applicants' desire to support the mission. So, to those applying for entry level positions, NEGOTIATE YOUR SALARY. The initial offer is made with the EXPECTATION that you will ask for and receive more. Even if you've never held a similar position and have always wanted to work for this org, negotiate. They will not withdraw the offer and other PAs I know successfully increased their salaries through offer negotiations.

The organization has struggled to provide an inclusive and equitable environment. Leadership is almost all white, as are most of the people in advocacy positions, while employees of color tend to hold positions within development, hr, accounting, and other support departments. Most employees recognize this as a huge problem, but the organization has taken only minimal steps to make necessary changes. I see a push to change messaging around environmental justice and the Big Green groups' history of whitewashing and racism, which I appreciate, but not a response to employee requests for a shift in the internal culture.

Different programs treat program assistants with different levels of respect. Every PA I met was overqualified for her (most women in these support roles) work and took the position to get a foot in the door at the organization. However, many programs overwork their PAs with administrative tasks that supervisors could accomplish more efficiently on their own if they took the time to learn how. This keeps PAs from engaging with the organization's mission and from taking advantage of opportunities for career growth. Further, while I was there, salaries for support staff were inadequate and HR horrible to deal with whenever this problem was raised.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:

So, if you want to stick to actual business hours, be prepared to feel like you're not putting in as much as those who choose to work outside those hours (including emailing), and be ready to spend the first hour or so of your day working on tasks you don't need your co-workers for.

- With some teams it's incredibly unclear who is charge until someone complains that they weren't involved in something after the fact. Other teams have clear roles, but produce work that takes more time to correct than is worth it to begin with. Not clear why either is acceptable.
